001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003import squidpony.Maker;
004
005import java.io.Serializable;
006import java.util.ArrayList;
007import java.util.Collection;
008import java.util.Collections;
009import java.util.Iterator;
010
011/**
012 * Meant to take a fixed-size set of items and produce a shuffled stream of them such that an element is never chosen in
013 * quick succession; that is, there should always be a gap between the same item's occurrences. This is an Iterable of
014 * T, not a Collection, because it can iterate without stopping, infinitely, unless you break out of a foreach loop that
015 * iterates through one of these, or call the iterator's next() method only a limited number of times. Collections have
016 * a size that can be checked, but Iterables can be infinite (and in this case, this one is).
017 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 5/21/2016.
018 * @param <T> the type of items to iterate over; ideally, the items are unique
019 */
020public class GapShuffler<T> implements Iterator<T>, Iterable<T>, Serializable {
021    private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
022    public IRNG rng;
023    private ArrayList<T> elements;
024    private int index;
025    private GapShuffler() {}
026
027    public GapShuffler(T single)
028    {
029        rng = new RNG();
030        elements = new ArrayList<>(1);
031        elements.add(single);
032        index = 0;
033    }
034    /**
035     * Constructor that takes any Collection of T, shuffles it with an unseeded RNG, and can then iterate infinitely
036     * through mostly-random shuffles of the given collection. These shuffles are spaced so that a single element should
037     * always have a large amount of "gap" in order between one appearance and the next. It helps to keep the appearance
038     * of a gap if every item in elements is unique, but that is not necessary and does not affect how this works.
039     * @param elements a Collection of T that will not be modified
040     */
041    public GapShuffler(Collection<T> elements)
042    {
043        this(elements, new RNG(new LongPeriodRNG()));
044
045    }
046
047    /**
048     * Constructor that takes any Collection of T, shuffles it with an unseeded RNG, and can then iterate infinitely
049     * through mostly-random shuffles of the given collection. These shuffles are spaced so that a single element should
050     * always have a large amount of "gap" in order between one appearance and the next. It helps to keep the appearance
051     * of a gap if every item in elements is unique, but that is not necessary and does not affect how this works.
052     * @param elements a Collection of T that will not be modified
053     */
054    public GapShuffler(Collection<T> elements, String seed)
055    {
056        this(elements, new RNG(new LongPeriodRNG(seed)));
057    }
058
059    /**
060     * Constructor that takes any Collection of T, shuffles it with the given RNG, and can then iterate infinitely
061     * through mostly-random shuffles of the given collection. These shuffles are spaced so that a single element should
062     * always have a large amount of "gap" in order between one appearance and the next. It helps to keep the appearance
063     * of a gap if every item in items is unique, but that is not necessary and does not affect how this works. The
064     * rng parameter is copied so externally using it won't change the order this produces its values; the rng field is
065     * used whenever the iterator needs to re-shuffle the internal ordering of items. I suggest that the IRNG should
066     * use {@link LongPeriodRNG} as its RandomnessSource, since it is in general a good choice for shuffling, or
067     * {@link XoshiroStarPhi32RNG} for GWT or other 32-bit platforms, but the choice is unlikely to matter in practice.
068     * @param items a Collection of T that will not be modified
069     * @param rng an IRNG that can be pre-seeded; will be copied and not used directly
070     */
071    public GapShuffler(Collection<T> items, IRNG rng)
072    {
073        this.rng = rng.copy();
074        elements = rng.shuffle(items);
075        index = 0;
076    }
077
078    /**
079     * Constructor that takes any Collection of T, shuffles it with an unseeded RNG, and can then iterate infinitely
080     * through mostly-random shuffles of the given collection. These shuffles are spaced so that a single element should
081     * always have a large amount of "gap" in order between one appearance and the next. It helps to keep the appearance
082     * of a gap if every item in elements is unique, but that is not necessary and does not affect how this works.
083     * @param elements a Collection of T that will not be modified
084     */
085    public GapShuffler(T[] elements)
086    {
087        this(elements, new RNG(new LongPeriodRNG()));
088    }
089
090    /**
091     * Constructor that takes any Collection of T, shuffles it with an unseeded RNG, and can then iterate infinitely
092     * through mostly-random shuffles of the given collection. These shuffles are spaced so that a single element should
093     * always have a large amount of "gap" in order between one appearance and the next. It helps to keep the appearance
094     * of a gap if every item in elements is unique, but that is not necessary and does not affect how this works.
095     * @param elements a Collection of T that will not be modified
096     */
097    public GapShuffler(T[] elements, CharSequence seed)
098    {
099        this(elements, new RNG(new LongPeriodRNG(seed)));
100    }
101
102    /**
103     * Constructor that takes any Collection of T, shuffles it with the given RNG, and can then iterate infinitely
104     * through mostly-random shuffles of the given collection. These shuffles are spaced so that a single element should
105     * always have a large amount of "gap" in order between one appearance and the next. It helps to keep the appearance
106     * of a gap if every item in items is unique, but that is not necessary and does not affect how this works. The
107     * rng parameter is copied so externally using it won't change the order this produces its values; the rng field is
108     * used whenever the iterator needs to re-shuffle the internal ordering of items. I suggest that the IRNG should
109     * use {@link LongPeriodRNG} as its RandomnessSource, since it is in general a good choice for shuffling, or
110     * {@link XoshiroStarPhi32RNG} for GWT or other 32-bit platforms, but the choice is unlikely to matter in practice.
111     * @param items a Collection of T that will not be modified
112     * @param rng an IRNG that can be pre-seeded; will be copied and not used directly
113     */
114    public GapShuffler(T[] items, IRNG rng)
115    {
116        this.rng = rng.copy();
117        elements = Maker.makeList(items);
118        rng.shuffleInPlace(elements);
119        index = 0;
120    }
121
122    /**
123     * Gets the next element of the infinite sequence of T this shuffles through. This class can be used as an
124     * Iterator or Iterable of type T.
125     * @return the next element in the infinite sequence
126     */
127    public T next() {
128        int size = elements.size();
129        if(size == 1)
130        {
131            return elements.get(0);
132        }
133        if(index >= size)
134        {
135            final int n = size - 1;
136            for (int i = n; i > 1; i--) {
137                Collections.swap(elements, rng.nextSignedInt(i), i - 1);
138            }
139            Collections.swap(elements, 1 + rng.nextSignedInt(n), n);
140            index = 0;
141        }
142        return elements.get(index++);
143    }
144    /**
145     * Returns {@code true} if the iteration has more elements.
146     * This is always the case for GapShuffler.
147     *
148     * @return {@code true} always
149     */
150    @Override
151    public boolean hasNext() {
152        return true;
153    }
154    /**
155     * Not supported.
156     *
157     * @throws UnsupportedOperationException always throws this exception
158     */
159    @Override
160    public void remove() {
161        throw new UnsupportedOperationException("remove() is not supported");
162    }
163
164    /**
165     * Returns an <b>infinite</b> iterator over elements of type {@code T}; the returned iterator is this object.
166     * You should be prepared to break out of any for loops that use this once you've gotten enough elements!
167     * The remove() method is not supported by this iterator and hasNext() will always return true.
168     *
169     * @return an infinite Iterator over elements of type T.
170     */
171    @Override
172    public Iterator<T> iterator() {
173        return this;
174    }
175}
